description:
My go to place for some spicy food. Must have hot & sour soup. It is the best so far. Ask for less spicy for starter. We have tried different dishes, so far they are all great.

Highly recommended
author: Jimmy D.

description: Came with a friend who knows the owner. She recommended the sweet and sour fish. It tasted really good! I also had their homemade chive and shrimp dumpling. It was good but the closing part of the dumpling was doughy. The five spiced beef was little salty for me. Other than that everything was good.
author: Jaylene L.

description: Da best combination fried rice! They've got that awesome flavor you're looking for. The chow mein noodles don't disappoint either!
author: Harper C.

description: The food was really delicious and not oily. We ordered chicken wings and Szechuan dan dan noodles. The wings were really crispy and pungent in taste. The noodles were also really chewy and not clumpy. The owners were super friendly. Will definitely come back.
author: LinQian S.

description:
The best hot and sour soup I've had my entire life--it an impeccable balance of savory, spicy, steamy, and sour. Most places go overboard w the vinegar taste, but Little Beijing hit everything on the spot. They were generous with the tofu and veggies too! Although the portions were massive, I went a little overboard and finished the entire M size soup. 

Photo is M size soup after two bowls were already scooped out. It had a good 6 bowls left out of it.
author: Briana Z.

description:
It's a pretty small restaurant. They have nine tables inside, two of which seats a large group. We came here for lunch on Thanksgiving Day, and the restaurant was almost full, maybe because it is known among the locals in the area. 

We ordered three dishes and a fried rice. Prices are affordable, most items are $8 or $9. They have a luncheon special during the weekdays from 11:30-3pm where dishes are only $6.50 or $6.95. 

Hunan beef: This was pretty good. The beef was tender. There's not a lot of meat however. This dish is a little bit spicy. 

Tofu and shrimp: Not my favorite dish. It was a bit lackluster. It would have probably tasted better if it was cooked spicy. 

Baby bok choy with black mushroom: Portion size is not really that big. The bok choy was cooked perfectly. It wasn't cooked for too long, so each bite was crunchy, exactly how it should be. 

Combination fried rice: Flavorful, but could use more meat. 

Overall, the food here is pretty good, but I wish they were more generous with their ingredients. They also deliver for free after 5pm if you purchase a $25 minimum.
author: Julia K.

description: I ordered from hear through Eat24 at 4:45. At 6:30, we still didn't have our food. I called, and the woman just kept saying, "We're just so busy. Kitchen is so busy." The driver had gone out, but didn't have our food, and she had no idea when the driver would be back. She gave me the option of cancelling the order, but by the time I did that and ordered from somewhere else, it would have been at least another hour, and I have two starving kids whose dinner time was 6:00. I didn't think it would be that much longer. The woman was completely uncaring and only cared about how busy she was. Totally unacceptable. We didn't get the food until 7:10. One kid's bedtime was 7:00. When I called to request a refund since we had to find other food before their food came, the woman at the restaurant hung up on me! Never again. I will never order from here again. The restaurant is completely mismanaged and the staff have zero customer service.
author: Amy B.

description: Jerry that works at little Beijing deserves 7 stars. He literally is the nicest and sweetest person and delivers the food quickly and seems like he is on top of things all the time.. 3 star for the rest of the staff.. non the less.. the food is amazing and if Jerry (might be misspelling his name) was the only person I had to deal with I would be the happiest customer ever. Very good food and I believe he is the one making it so I know it's good cuz I trust him with it. Thank you Jerry.. you made my night complete with some yumminess.. you da bomb. :)
author: Lana R.

description:
We tried to go to a restaurant right next door, but it was closed. Am I ever glad for that! The food was so good and modestly priced. It was authentic and well done. The atmosphere was oddly quiet, but probably because everyone around us was too busy eating to talk

Note: their food is served family style. 

We ordered:
-House special Shanghai Big Noodles. Yes, they really are big, and also come with little bits of the most tender beef I've ever tasted. 10/10, would recommend.
-Sizzling rice soup. It was delicious and they prepared it for you at your table, so, it's like dinner and a little show. 
-Black Mushroom and Snow Peas. Not amazing, but still good.
-Side of white rice. Idk what they did to it, but it was really good. Maybe just a hint of sweetness?

I don't know why this place has 3.5 stars as of 1/1/18. I hope it continues to rise.
author: Isaac C.

description: This is my first review. We ordered food and it took 1 hour for all of our food to get here. We got the Mapo Tofu and there was no meat and tasted very bland; it was appalling. Then we got the Szechuan spicy meat, guess what? Only 3 pieces of meat!!! The soup was bland but the noodles, imo, was pretty good. The pancakes were heavenly though, the only good food here. I would not recommend going here again.
author: Elvis H.

description:
Food tastes good, service is great, and portion size is quite large for the price. You get your money's worth here! 

I recommend the house special fried fish fillet, the Beijing string beans, and the hot and sour soup. The fish fillet and string beans are super flavorful. There is a bit of spiciness involved, but just a slight kick. Nothing too crazy unless you cannot take a lick of spicy food. The hot and sour soup was nice and sour/hot as well.

I wish this place was closer to my house! I would be ordering delivery quite frequently. Maybe it's a good thing this place is a little ways away then. All in all, would definitely stop by if I am in the area, there is decent parking around, and craving the above-mentioned dishes.
author: Kristi T.

description: Good food for a great prices! it's a good deal. Your typical Chinese restaurant in the sunset. Please be advise, may contain msg.
author: Kathy N.

description:
Friendly service.
I love the ma po tofu!
The food is okay but the price is reasonable!
author: Candice L.

description: We stumbled upon this restaurant when my Dad was hospitalized at St. Mary's. It's a small place but the food is fantastic. This has become one of our favorite restaurant. To us, they have the best hot & sour soup. There's a line to be seated most of the time. They also deliver within the vicinity.
author: Dorcas C.

description: Delicious food and price is fair. Great hole in wall spot for authentic Mandarin food.
author: Sherman M.

description: An excellent Chinese restaurant. The food is always fresh, the spices are well-balanced, and the environment is always clean.
author: Stephen Y.

description: Authentic northern Chinese food at a reasonable price! Also with friendly service. Good and easy spot if you find yourself in the neighborhood.
author: Rose J.

description: This is for the delivery.  I come here often and like eating here but some days you just can't get there.  I ordered a whole bunch of food, and notice that they said, if I order a certain amount ($35.00), you get free egg rolls.  Well, I ask them how much was my order, and it was about $34.70.  .30 cents.  So you can't give me free eggrolls because it's .30 off?  Uh, bad customer service?  It would be different if it was $2.00 or more but really?  Needless to say, one less Chinese place I'm ordering from.
author: Hallie S.

description: Don't ever get the dandan mian, it's pretty bad... I've been on a search for a go to place for these noodles for a while now, so when we came here I was excited to try these out. I was very disappointed and even got a bit sick after eating these. They were literally noodles with some peanut sauce on it, but might as well have just been some peanut butter mixed with a few other ingredients. It was very oily and made my stomach very upset, which is something since I usually don't get sick, even after accidentally eating expired yogurt and milk...
author: Larissa L.

description:
Want to give this place 4.5 due to the ambiance, but can't give half stars, so 5 it is. That's how happy we were with the food, the wait time, and the wait staff. We walked in and immediately felt at home here. The man (who I'm assuming is the manager) smiled very warmly and asked us where we'd like to sit. The wait staff is so friendly!! We decided to order a lot of the house specials per their recommendation and were so glad we did.

The green onion pancakes are to DIE FOR. They are so crispy on the outside and layered so thinly on the inside. Difficult to describe, but we loved it.

We'd also recommend the chive and egg stuffed in a "box"... Not sure what it's called in English. So yummy.

We also really appreciate how they give free side soy sauce peanuts and pickled vegetables at the beginning of the meal. When we ran out during the meal, they brought us more because they saw how much we were enjoying it. Prompt service.
author: Deanna C.

description:
I went here for lunch, I had the Kung Pao Chicken, the tea and rice were included. Everything was very good.  The customer service was excellent and they were pretty busy for 1:30.
I'll come back again. I want to try the Dan Dan Mein.
author: Gary G.

description:
Ordered for Delivery

Started with the Chicken wings, then onto the beef fried rice, white rice, and an other for kung pao beef. 

The chicken wings were nice and crispy and not too salty. 

The fried rice was a nice size portion and was great, the white rice was not very sticky, (b00) and the beef was ok. Hot and tasty and the delivery service was quite fast. not bad for a delivery spot. 

cheers!
author: Benjamin B.

description: I come here with a large group for my birthday each year. Lots of delicious foods. Green Onion pancakes and dumplings all around.
author: Josh G.

description: Solid, basic, Chinese food in the sunset neighborhood.  Nothing to go out of your way for, but we would definitely order delivery from here.  We had dinner here and while we and another couple were the only ones in the restaurant, the service was very slow and we had to ask for things several times.  The phone orders were constant.  The food was basically good and had the basic Chinese menu you can find anywhere.  Would likely not go out of our way to come here, but will definitely be ordering delivery in the future.
author: Steven B.

description:
its qood food at lunch time and good value,it does not get busy at lunch so its quick service
the food is a step above most Chinese  food places,if your in the area at lunch its worth checking out,opens at 11.30 am
author: cc c.

description:
Please be careful. Last time we went there, there were a ga-zillion COCKROACHES.UGH!!!

Just look alongside the baseboards, there's families of them. When we alerted the proprietress, she was nonchalant about it. All of us couldn't stomach the thought that they were crawling around near our feet and might even be in one of our dishes. So we walked out.

Now every time I think of the place, I can't disassociate the cockroaches from this restaurant's food. And I get nauseous. This is one way to lose weight huh?

So sad since I used to like it.
author: priya k.

description: Food here taste like the kind I can make at home. Dumplings, soup, blah blah. It came out professionally though. Sad I can't give it higher rating but it is what it is. I would not go out of my way to come here. Fast friendly professional service non the less.
author: Keit K.

description:
Got delivery from here. Took 2 hours. 2 HOURS!!!

I got fried rice, and it had chunks of MSG in it. Absolutely horrible. Look elsewhere.
author: Scott H.

description: One of my favorite Chinese restaurant in SF, food is delicious and service is good. I highly recommend to have a try on it. I almost go to the restaurant every week
author: 尧

description: Came here for Mother's Day, because we walked out another place after 2 hours wait with a reservation. Short wait for a table at 7PM. Order 10 dishes, so I start with the bad one. dandan mian no like the real thing, just peanut favor sauce over some cold noodle. Now good dishes were the green onion pancake, dumplings, sweet and sour fish, lamp tofu, and the beef chow fun.
author: David Y.

description:
Little Beijing doesn't offer much in the way of decor. they just offer cheap eats. lunch special are way cheap, starting at 5.50, noodle dishes 6.25+

eats: mabo tofu (lunch special (5.5)
-everything tasted fresh
-flavorful mabo tofu, spicy at times
-rice a tad mushy, 
-good value, 4 stars

take outs:
-friendly service
-doesn't open on time.
-menu lists hand pulled noodles, skeptical, probably machine pulled.
-dumplings, onion pancakes also listed.
author: Victor G.

description: My favorite Chinese go-to place around sunset neighborhood. I have been going here for over 10years and food taste always the same. Owner is super friendly to customers and also they do delivery if you order 10-15 dollars. Place is very quite mostly and but when they get busy they are super busy. Comparable with San Tung in lrving st. Must Try!
author: Stella K.

description:
This is my favorite little restaurant in San Francisco.  We had been going there every week for quite some time now.   We tried a variety of dishes over the years; everything is really good.  Our favorites are dumplings, chive pockets, beef noodle soups, tea duck, string beans, and spicy chicken wings.  The dumplings and chive pockets are hand made by the owner; she says that's how she ensures the taste is consistent.  She sometimes stays up past midnight to make the batch for next day.  All the noodle dishes use freshly hand made noodles and are quite good.  

The service is fast, but there could be a wait on weekends.  The owner has to work very, very hard every time I see her.  Sometimes her friends (customers dining at the time) would jump in and help her serve the tables.  I asked why she doesn't hire additional help; she says the business is inconsistent; when they are busy, everyone seems to show up all at once.  However, the place could sometimes be empty on weekdays, and that's why she can't afford another full time employee.  So for those that complains long delivery time, please understand that this small business can't afford to hire extra help, and things do get a little crazy sometimes.  In fact, I would never order delivery unless you like mediocre food. Chinese food tastes best when they are fresh.  If you leave hot food in take out boxes, everything starts to taste soggy and over cooked.
author: El C.

description:
Wanted to try Sun Tea on Noriega, but I didn't know they were closed already! :( So... had take out from here instead cause I was really craving some Shanghainese breakfast!

1. Savory Rice Roll
The rice roll is decent, though I rather make them my own. I love how they use regular chinese donut instead of the aged crispy kind. However, the donut lacked in consistency since it started out soft and crispy to hard and crunchy (to the point that I couldn't bite into it anymore)! Also, there was way too much sticky rice and not enough fillings! For $3ish, it's not too bad given the size! 

2. Green Onion Pancake
Eh, it's alright. It was VERY oily and I prefer my green onion pancake thin, light, airy, and crispy (Taiwanese food stand kind). This, on the other hand, was thick and dense. Not a big fan of this, and probably won't order it again if I come back next time!
author: Michelle L.

description: Ownership change alert it appears.  Frazzled female under duress.  She's always blabbering how busy they are.  Whatever missy, just get my order cookin' and delivered pronto!  Food is mediocre at best so not really sure why we order from here.
author: Joel M.

description:
I came here for two items only and that's all I need from Little Beijing. Spicy chicken with either tofu or string beans and hot and sour soup. They're both so good and I crave it from time to time. 

I'm sure their other items are just as great, but whenever I come here... I NEED to order the spicy chicken. 

Spicy chicken lunch plate over rice is $6 which is a steal!
author: Nancy N.

description:
It was about 10:00 p.m. on a Saturday night and my boyfriend and I were pretty hungry.  We didn't want to cook, but didn't want fast food.  We hopped in the car and drove around to see what was open still- and Little Beijing Restaurant was the first place that caught our eye.

Even this late, the place had 3 other groups eating.  I was kind of impressed.  The place definitely wasn't anything fancy in terms of decor, but it worked.  My boyfriend and I chose a couple of the house specials off the menu.

Spicy dumplings: these were actually surprisingly pretty spicy.  They came out nice and hot and they were pretty full of meat.  The flavor itself was pretty mediocre; but it was alright.  The portion is pretty large too.

Noodles: don't remember the specific name, but it had some sesame-peanutty sauce to it.  It had mushrooms and pork as well.  The portion of noodles itself was a bit ridiculous- it was a huge bowl food of noodles.  Unfortunately, the noodles kind of clumped together and it was a bit difficult to mix the sauce through the noodles.

Overall, the food was pretty okay.  It was hot and filled me up.  I appreciate that they give you a free side of soy-sauce peanuts, pickled vegetables, and tea; although I didn't really care for these all that much.  The service was helpful, but not overly friendly.  Price is fair too; the meal was about $18 after tax and tip.

Notes:
-Fluffy snow is next door!
author: Samantha L.

description: I have been to little beijing restaurant for a few years now. They have switched owners quite a few times, but the food and recipes have stayed the same which I appreciate. I know there are tons of other good chinese food places around the area, but people need to give this place a chance! The food is delicious and for an affordable price. Its not dirt cheap but its still affordable! I really hope they get more business because I love this place. Every time I visit they hardly have any customers inside =[ Their spicy won ton is AMAZING!! I order it every time I come. Yelpers! Give this place a chance and try it out!
author: Kelly S.

description:
I used to get to-go from here all the time for lunch. Lunch specials (before 3pm) are $6. So worth it because they give you large portions as well. 

The A La Szechuan Pork and H&W are really good! The spicy chicken is good too but I find it on the oily side. I end up breaking out once I eat it. I also like the rice burritos (sweet one) they have on Saturday's.
author: Cheryl P.

description:
This has got to be one of my favorite authentic northern Chinese cuisine!
Even though this is a hole in the wall, its family owned and priced very reasonably!

Lunch special including hot sour soups, white rice and a protein dish for $6... Go figure

Shrimp and Chive dumplings, General Tsou Chicken (ask them to do the same for Shrimp).  Tan Tan noodles.

Been going here for 35+ years since college days at SFSU.

If you want the real Chinese, and not the Americanized PF Chang corporate mock up, this is the place to come!
author: David H.

description:
Manager / waiter was so friendly.  He was a happy guy.  I like happy people!  Made me want to be there.  It was crowded, but he didn't make us feel rushed.  Maybe it wasn't the manager, but I think someone else referenced to the middle aged Chinese waiter.  I feel like that has to be the same guy! 

Food was good.  The noodle soup was not the best I have ever had.  Flavor was not doing it for me.  However, the chives pancakes = SO GOOD!!  Here's a link to what it is: http://leutheuser.blogs.com/photos/uncategorized/chivepancake2.jpg

I don't know what it is actually called.  It's my guess.  But that is what I am referring to.  Get it!!  I only know the name of it in Chinese.

Their appetizers were also pretty big.  The pork ears and gan si (shredded bean curd sheets) were really big!  Pork ears were spicy and super oily.  But so delicious.  The leftover oil / chili sauce was good for dipping the chives pancakes in.

I wouldn't mind coming back if I lived closer.  Too bad I live on the other side of the city :(  Wish there were more places like this near soma!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Their hot and sour soup is pretty special...definitely not the type you get from Chinese buffets or soup inclusive lunch specials.  I also like their stuffed "hot pockets" - I'm sure they're not call that, but that's what I refer to them as.  They're stuffed with glass noodles, chives, scramble eggs and I think pork too.  Noodle soups are decent (noodles are made in-house).  Not the fastest service, but then again I don't recall having to wait for a table from my many visits here.
author: Leland H.

description: A hole in the wall, authentic Northern Chinese restaurant.  Place is on the smaller side, but the green onion pancakes are delicious. My favorite here is the hot and sour soup. For those wary of eating spicy, General Cho's Pork is the best in town.
author: Richard W.

description: Not bad but to be fair I only got the spicy wontons and they are not very spicy and not very flavorful
author: Dana L.

description:
We were craving Taiwanese breakfast one morning and saw that this place had the rice roll. I was excited to find a place in SF since there are not a lot of Taiwanese places to eat in the city. Our overall experience was okay. It was one of my friend's first time trying Taiwanese food so I was disappointed when it fell short. 

What we ordered: 

- Beef noodle soup: I did not like it at all. I've had way better. The meat was hard and it was bland. We ordered two bowls because we got too excited and couldn't even finish one. 

-Rice Roll: It was good. I've had better but it did its' job. 

-Cold Chicken Noodles: This was the best dish we ordered. It was good. It didn't have as much vegetables as I would have hoped. And it was overly drenched in the sauce. 

-Rice Cakes with Pork and Cabbage: It was okay. Just a little bland.

-Soy milk: Meh. 

The only good thing is that this place has delivery so I would order a rice roll and maybe cold noodles to be delivered but I would not make a trip out.
author: Thatcher H.

description:
We ordered from Little Beijing for delivery Saturday night. It was delicious! My husband ate the entire General Cho chicken and he's still talking about it today! 
We also had the Szechuan beef and snow peas with black mushrooms. 
We will definitely order from here again!
author: Margaret M.

description: This place was the only place that was open nearby. The wonton soup was bland, the service was terrible and to top it all off we saw a COCKROACH on the wall right next to us. We immediately lost our appetite. Do yourself a favor and don't risk eating a roach coming here.
author: Sherry L.

description: Solid Chinese food for a reasonable price. Judging by the other reviews, it seems like this place has had a rocky past, but there are good folks running things at the moment! They were quite gracious in handling my pickup orders, and the food was great.
author: Derryl C.

description: Delivery order was pretty mediocre.  Heavy on the sauce and sugar.  Fried rice was a disappointment.  I'll give them a second chance given they do have some of my favorites on their menu.
author: Eric C.

description:
Really Great Little Place They Have Here!

Cheap Prices & Great Taste!

Green Onion Pancake Is A Great Starter!
Hunan Shrimp & Black Bean Chicken Had Good Portion Sizes.

Won't Disappoint! =)
author: Nathan C.

description: My husband and I both unknowingly ordered food from here on the same night for a group we host weekly. When we realized it, we went back immediately to cancel it. We live close by. Luckily, only 1/6 items was made so we were able to cancel the rest of the order! All in all, we ordered about 3 green onion pancakes (needed some salt) , 1 fried rice, 1 white rice, and 4 protein items. For about $50, we fed 10 people easily. This place gets a lot of take-out orders so if you call ahead, you'll save yourself some time.
author: Crys L.

description:
7:15PM. Friday night. Ordered a bunch 'o food for delivery.

9:20PM now. Called three times. Each time they tell me 10 minutes. Still no food. Two hours? Really? TWO HOURS AND STILL NO FOOD????!!!! But, but... the restaurant is only 10 minutes away -- MAX! Thinking I should be heading out to find some food elsewhere. Even if it does show up, will be cold as hell.

9:40PM Yay! Food! You want a TIP??????? After more than two and a half hours???? No WAY!

9:50PM We're digging in.

To be continued....

--------

Now for the food review... I have a question. Is there one huge chinese kitchen factory in San Francisco with massive vats of the same stuff? Because this place tastes exactly like sooooo many other delivery places in the west side of SF (Sunset, Richmond, Glen Park). Bottom line.... Meh.

Here's what we sampled:

Chive, Shrimp, Pork Dumplings (12) $6.95
-- OK

Shrimp Chow Fun $7.55
-- Oily mushy noodles, bland shrimp

Vegetable Fried Rice (free with order)
--- Bland. Cheap frozen diced vegetables.

Walnut Prawns $9.95
-- Bland frozen (for near eternity) shrimp.

Seafood Deluxe Soup (S) $6.95
-- OMG... DELUXE???? I would have expected a cornucopia of shellfish and fish. Not so. A couple of shrimp and scollop pieces. The rest, frozen diced vegetables. Soup the consistency of corn huskers lotion. Corn or rice starch. No flavor. At all.

Sesame Beef $8.55
-- Dried out beef. Softened with artificial tenderizer. Smothered in sugar.

Beijing Sweet and Sour Spare Ribs $8.55
-- Dried out pork chops. Not spare ribs. Fried in oily batter. Drowning in sugar.

Black mushrooms with snow peas $8.25
-- Bland. Not fresh. A couple of mushrooms. The rest were fiber-y snow peas.


None of the dishes with prawns had much taste. The prawns tasted bland. Overall, any dish's taste aspects relied mostly on sugar, salt and oil. 

One "star". Four "blehs".
author: The V.

description:
This place has Been here forever and it shows. Stuck in 1970's décor  
Decent flavors and reasonable portions.
i have not been here since i have visited Beijing twice on separate trips.
maybe a return visit is in order.
author: Jeff W.

description:
service can certainly be improved.
san xian noodle soup was good noodle itself was average
double pi was good
author: Diane W.

description:
I'm a fan. Hope they deliver again soon. Best Chinese Delivery I've had in the city so far... and that's saying a lot

12 Pork Dumplings
$ 6.55
Perfectly cooked. 

Beijing Sweet and Sour Pork
$ 8.55
delicious, crisp, not soggy at all, not over sauced or filled with peppers and onions. 


Chicken Fried Rice
$ 6.25
Perfect. No recycled clumped together steamed rice. fried through and through with delicious seasonings. If it came out of a rice cooker, I couldn't tell.  
1
General Cho's Chicken
$ 8.55 
It was good, Nice contrast from the pork.
author: Vinny T.

description:
The service seemed disjointed, with the waitress being a bit confused about how to best "serve" us. In order to avoid any confusion, it is probably best to just tell her exactly what you want and to just leave it at that.

Although a lot of Asian restaurants may not put cleanliness as a top priority, slightly dirty water cups and funny tasting, slightly cloudy water is definitely a bit on the side of unacceptable.

Overall, most of the food items our party ordered, bordered on the side of slightly bland. In particular, the beef noodle soup broth was watery; the noodles also had a strange textural consistency to it, being slightly overcooked and bland. The only saving grace of the meal were the chicken wings and stir-fried string beans. The chicken wings had a nice crunchy texture; which was complimented by the spicy sweet sauce. The string beans maintained their crunchy snap, and was seasoned well.
author: Joshua S.

description:
A small family run restaurant with pleasant service. Started with their house special Pork dumplings. They were one of the best dumpling I've had in awhile, being very moist with finely minced pork. The Green onion pancake was also tops, crispy and flaky crust and not to thin nor thick, try it with the dipping sauce that came with the dumplings! 

Sizzling rice soup - typical standard fare. 

Tea smoked chicken - good smoked flavor, but way too dry out. 

Beijing Eggplant - very good flavor with quarter tomatoes, garlic & green onions. 

Beijing Bean sauce noodles - worth a try, very generous portion with good intense bean sauce compliments the shanghai style noodles.
author: Wolfy W.

description: This Chinese restaurant is another one on Noriega. I had beef chow fun and tea-smoked duck. The meal was fine and I have no complaints.
author: Denise C.

description:
We just tried this place for the first time and only because another place we wanted to try was closed. Little Beijing looks like one of those old throwback restaurants, which is decidedly not hip whatsoever. 

But the vegetarian section is labeled "Healthy Food", so we figured we try it. The guy in charge is really friendly and he quickly brought out some sweet vinegar cabbage, some strange marinated peanuts in the shell, and tea for the table, so that was nice.

We ordered two very different tofu dishes (there was a different one he couldn't really explain and said we wouldn't like...hmmm...). Both were large, came quickly, and were somewhat surprisingly really good.

Serendipity struck again!
author: Veg V.

description: Listen folks...Ya have to know what to order here. I base my review on several years of ordering what has proven to me to be 5 stars and what we order here all of the time. Scallion Pancakes, General Tsous Chicken and Beef Fried Rice are as addictive as crack! Broccoli sauteed in garlic sauce and the Pot Stickers won't disappoint either.
author: Steven B.

description:
What happened to one of our favorite Chinese Restaurants? Wow... what a disappointment in all facets of the meal.

1) As some of the other reviewers, mentioned the service. We used to be served by this nice, friendly Chinese waiter. Either he was off tonight, or no longer works there? Anyway, the Asian lady who served us provided non-existent service. Some others present (perhaps the delivery people) brought us the cabbage appetizer, she seemed annoyed even when I asked for water. During the meal (needless to say) she never showed up. It must have been because the place was packed (only one other table dining at the time), imagine if they had 4 concurrent tables. 

2) The food. we ordered 2 House specialities, the recommended , spicy chicken (YUK), and salt-pepper spare ribs (didn't care for this either). We're used to really, really enjoying our dishes. Either we picked some poor dishes tonight, or perhaps there's new ownership of this restaurant. 

3) I recommended to my wife , let's go there tonight, and I've apologized repeatedly all the way home. I like authentic, and great Chinese food, and this place used to be great. Tonight, the green onion pancakes (still good, I admit), and the rice were the best parts of the meal. Truly sad. 

If it's the same ownership, and the waiter was off tonight, I'll let the restaurant message me and tell me this, and perhaps I'll be willing to try again (IF and only IF he would be the one serving me). This was some of the worse service I have experienced, and the food sad to say matched it tonight. 

Time to find some new places to go.....
author: G L.

description: I've had good experiences eating there.  But do not order delivery.  We placed an order at 4pm.  It is now 5:35 and we are still waiting.
author: Mike Y.

description:
(See pics)

More like 3.3 stars.

I was attracted to the handwritten Chinese soy drink and deep fried doughnut. Of course I missed the point that they serve it only on the weekends. I apparently was starving.

A local joint. I love Chinese appetizers as the main dish. To curb the overly starving appetite at the same time spicing up, they served cold boiled peanuts and sour cabbage. Both were great starters.

I had the shrimp pancake, which was good but I do think onion cake would be better because I liked stronger taste.

I also had the Wo Tip, the Chinese pan-fried dumplings. They were pretty big with lots of meat and were of pretty good taste.

As I was going to the bathroom and passing by the kitchen, I could smell the great spicy wok fried beans with lots of chili sauce. To not let my extra appetite overwhelm my rationale, I tried really hard not to get a takeout.

But I'd be back for those spicy dishes.
author: T L.

description: So terrible. the way too terrible. I doubt have they ever salt when they cooking. I order the spicy dish and it was not spicy at all, I doubt whether I have problems with my tongue. SHITTY PLACE
author: Jingran L.

description: Simply great Chinese food!  Not greasy and fantastic flavors.  My faves are the green onion pancakes, the mongolian beef, and cashew chicken.  I've only had it delivered so I'm not sure what it's like in the restaurant - it's always here in an hour or less when I order online.
author: Mark C.

description: OMG i hate the hostess soooo hard. She mad dogs everyone that comes in ( wtf i'm asian too!) is on her phone or ignoring the cooks that the food is ready.  You literally have to go up to her and ask for a refill on water. She seriously doesn't give a shit about you. Then comes running outside after my friends and I demanding a tip. Oh hells fucking no. You ignore us the whole time then have the nerve to demand a tip?
author: Rater 1.

description:
While the food is moderately decent the lady here is completely rude and has no idea what customer service is. I ordered pick up and while I came in and waited at the pay counter she continued to chat with friends at a table. Upon realizing my frustration, she walked to the back, brought out my food, and didn't give it to me but instead placed it on a table and told me to grab it. When I paid her she asked if I wanted the full change....uh damn right I do. 

Why are ppl like this still in business
author: zaira a.

description: Despite the dingy interior and lack of customers, this place is surprisingly good. Everything we ordered tasted good. I'd stick to the items that have house special written next to it. Another random note is that this is the first chinese restaurant in a long time that refilled my water without me asking. Bonus points. China north is still my favorite around here, but I will add this place to my rotation.
author: M C.

description: This is my favorite neighborhood Chinese restaurant even though I don't live in the neighborhood.  I have been coming here for nearly 20 years now.  Recommendations:  crab and cheese dumplings (eat in only), green onion pancake, General Cho's Shrimp (great combination of sweet, garlic and vinegar flavors) and Beijing string beans.  There are a lot of other great options to mix in, and after all this time I am still finding new things to try and love.  It is a great value, and I always leave with tasty leftovers for the next day after ordering too much.  Try to eat in if possible.
author: James C.

description: Came here on a friend's recommendation. The place is small and the quality is decent. The staff are OK and the place is dirty. The portions are small. That's about it in 20 words or less.
author: M C.

description: Delivery from this place takes forever. They used to be quick and their food's ok but since they moved to Noriega they're too busy to handle it.
author: Nancy S.

description:
The service may be excellent, but the food is barely average.  My friend took me here for the green onion pancakes and yes, they were good, but the Shrimp and Walnut entree was very sub-par (the shrimp were deep fried), the General Cho's chicken was nothing special, and even the Hot and Sour soup was very forgettable.  The mu shu pork was okay but I've had better in plenty of places (most notably, Xiao Loong in West Portal).

In a town where good Chinese food can be found easily, I see no reason to waste time at this place unless you're a big fan of mediocrity.
author: Jill T.

description: We got the wonton soup and the Peking crispy chicken...Amazeballs! The soup was delicious and the wontons were tasty. The server was really nice and attentive. Would definitely recommend this place!
author: Elizabeth K.

description: Mmmmmmm, some more Mandarin food finds.  We came here last night & are fans of this place; the owner, Jenny, is very hospitable; making suggestions & getting to know you.  The atmosphere is bare bones, the restaurant a bit smaller than some around, but a wonderful atmosphere.  The spicy won tons are sumptuous with a lite wrapper, seasoned ground pork filling, & a wonderful chili sauce that subtly becomes spicy once you bite into each dumpling.  The green onion pancake is one of the best I have had with layers of dough & onions & perfectly fried.  The general Tsao's chicken is crispy & greasless with tongue tingling hot sauce.  The hunan beef is tender with fresh broccoli, carrots, & zuchini in a wonderful chili paste.  The Beijing string beans are crisp in a wonderful bean sauce.  The bean sauce noodles are to die for with hand pulled noodles, thinly sliced pork, & vegetables in a wonderful bean paste.  Sure, we ordered a little more, but we like having leftovers for the next day.  Note, all of the dumplings, pancakes, & noodles are made in house.  Anything on the menu that says house special is the way to go for anyone not sure; needless to say, it was second nature for me being a Chinese efficianato.  Round it off with a Ching Dao or in my mother's case, some red wine & you will not be disappointed.  The owner loved my limited Mandarin.  So, for excellent Mandarin cuisine in a smaller friendly atmosphere with excellent food at low prices, Little Beijing cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guyws.
author: Brian S.

description:
The four stars is only for their hot and sour soup. which is amazing. on these recent (very) cold san francisco nights, Little Beijing's hot and sour soup is all I want. A small size order (~$5) is a meal in itself, and sure warms my tummy!

aaaand for the rest of their dishes/lunch plates, I've tried a couple. they're okay, fairly mediocre if I must say, not bad but not anything I can't stop thinking about (like their hot and sour soup!). the main guy there usually taking the orders seems to always be super chipper, which is kinda funny :D

bottom line, if you like hot and sour soup. THIS IS YOUR PLACE!
author: Jennie L.

description:
Little Beijing is a favorite of my GF's parents, so I've had a chance to come here many times and try a lot of different dishes.  It's a cute little hole in the wall on Noriega that serves up typical Mandarin dishes.  The food is okay although it's been growing on me.  The first few times we went, the parents had ordered everything for us and you know how that works.  Inevitably there were only like 2 things I really wanted to eat and the rest was, well, bleck.  As of recent, however, I've made more of an effort to be involved in the ordering process and have ordered some dishes that have turned out to be quite delicious.  As a result, I'm eating more and more, and liking Little Beijing more and more, every time we go there.

They give complimentary peanuts and vinegar soaked cabbage to every table.  I've never seen that at a Chinese restaurant before, so that was interesting.  I'm not a fan of the peanuts however the cabbage is sweet/sour and can get addicting if you're not careful.

The hot and sour soup doesn't stand out from any other restaurants, however be forewarned that this can sometimes come out unexpectedly extra spicy.   

The dumplings and fried onion cake are both great ways to start your meal.  The shrimp dumplings are so succulent and ooze with soup when you bite into them.  The fried onion cake is quite tasty as well.  It comes out piping hot and crispy.  I've found it quite tasty to spread the chili sauce from the table all over the onion cake before eating.  We've also ordered the chicken wings a couple times.  While the wings are usually nice and spicy, they don't come close to the wings at San Tung or Marnee Thai.  

For the entrees, we usually just get a couple noodle dishes.  I can't remember what any of them are called, however none of them are great in terms of flavor.  We seem to always have noodle leftovers. 

One entrée that did stand out for me was the orange chicken!  I ordered that for the first time last week after seeing it on another table and it was fabulous.  I know what you must be thinking; I only like this because I'm white, and I probably like the orange chicken at Panda Express too.  LOL, that is so wrong!  Panda orange chicken sucks.  The one they serve at Little Beijing is far superior.  It's drenched in sauce, yet still super crispy.  The meat is all chicken breast, which I greatly appreciate and there are no pieces that are just batter with no meat (something you will find is often the case at Panda).

Little Beijing is definitely a place to come get your Chinese food fix.  It's not as oily and dirty as other Chinese restaurants and the food tastes pretty good.  I look forward to continuing to eat here many times to come with the family.
author: Timothy C.

description:
Finally I decided to come here today, and was pleasantly surprised! The BF and I had cravings for some tasty Chinese-American food, and after trying other places we had gotten pretty jaded. Little Beijing, however, really impressed! 

We each got the lunch special: my bf got the "General Cho's" chicken and I got the Szechuan eggplant.  They have about 30 different items to choose from the special, and everything was under $6. Each came with a bowl of white rice and a cup of Hot & Sour soup. The special is available Monday-Friday until 3pm, however it is still available at other times and on weekends but will cost an extra 50 cents. Pretty sweet deal! Especially since the portions were pretty big. The BF and I ended up sharing our dishes, and by the time we were full, we still had enough to take home. Total for the bill was $12. STEAL.

The chicken made in small, bite-sized pieces that were reeeally crispy and smothered in the slightly spicy brown sauce and succulent garlic chips. It was very flavorful. The eggplant, also served with a spicy brown sauce, was just as delicious. Both items were labeled as spicy on the menu, but they actually weren't spicy that it burned your mouth. 

Service (just one waitress during lunch today) was friendly and prompt.

I'd LOVE to come back to this place and try their more authentic Beijing dishes, but I think the BF and I have already become instant regulars.
author: Trang N.

description:
I've come here a few times...and I've never thought of this place as having authentic Beijing food. However, the food is decent and cheap.

I really like getting the green onion pancakes and eating it with the sweet soy milk. The spicy dumplings here are also quite scrumptious. 

I don't like is the dan dan or the jia jia noodles here. Neither dish is flavored right...both seemed to watered down. Beijing people like strong flavors with lots of salt! The noodles here are ehhh.
author: Margaret R.

description: I came here a few times and they never fail to serve us quick as possible. Always get the spicy wonton soup, it's a must try Yelpers!!
author: Krystal S.

description: I really like green bell peppers. Plenty of them in the sweet and sour pork. Small pieces of pork, but were really good. We got served promptly. An OK place, we just ordered the American type stuff since we had been drinking and needed it to be simple. It hit the spot and that's what was needed. Like the Werewolves of London song, "gonna get a big dish of beef chow mein". Cause we were hungry like the wolf. :P Ha
author: Scott A.

description:
It has been over a year since I last dined here with the family. I am not very familiar with good Shanghai cuisine but this place will do for the average person not looking for anything extraordinary. 

We ordered a bowl of the sweet soybean milk with crispy flour roll ( dou jiang &  you tiao), green onion "pancake", savory sticky rice roll (), beef hand-pulled noodle soup, and dan dan noodles w/sesame paste ().

The soybean milk is likely pre-made since it came out really fast, followed by the crispy flour roll. The soy milk was decent. Wipe the spoons clean yourself because there was some residue on the upper end from excessive use. Don't forget to stir the sugar at the bottom before serving in smaller bowls. The crispy flour roll is on the worse end since it is too fried that it is as solid as a rock. I like to soften it by dipping it in the soy milk.

The next dish is the green onion pancake. This is one of the best in the meal as the pancake is not thin like many other places. It is fresh out of the kitchen so it is super crispy and extremely hot when you take a bite. Be careful! Then the savory sticky rice roll came shortly after. I love rice rolls and have since I was a toddler; it's not bad here having been lacking it for months. There is a lot of rice to the roll and a small crispy flour roll which is good. 

The two bowls of noodles came last. The beef hand-pulled noodle was pretty good but I like mine spicy. The noodles are great but the quality of the beef was a bit lower than I expect. There is a good amount of choy in the soup but for some reason the soup smelled like wonton soup even though it clearly tasted beef.

The dan dan noodles were my least favored entree. My mom expected the soup-style that Hong Kong serves but the one that was served has dry noodles with sesame paste (ma jiang). It's sort of like the infamous zha jiang noodles but with a worse sauce. I would recommend pretty much everything except the dan dan noodles.

I was pretty surprised that it was actually somewhat busy today. There were two servers anxiously waiting to take your order and bringing you your food but slow at refilling tea and checking on things. Seating can be a bit cramped depending on where you are seated.
author: Dominic T.

description: Love this place. Order there almost everyday! They're all very friendly and the food is definitely worth the price! Check out the lunch specials.
author: Rob T.

description: Great delivery experience. Pig ear, chive pancake were good. Looking forward to trying more.
author: Chen Z.

description: My GF recommended this place so we tried it out. Food was delicious and the service was good. We had the walnut prawns, the cold combination delight and potstickers. Very nicely cooked and was more than enough for both of us.
author: Greg W.

description: Spicy Chicken (LA ZHI JI in chinese) is the best here. I eat it at least once a week, if I didnt have to talk so much at work, I would eat it everyday... lol. its Super GARLICY. The garlic sauteed veggies there are really yum too. On saturdays they have Rice Burritos, they have the salty and sweet one. I love the salty one. All the other dishes i had here was so good too.  I bet they would get more business if they remodeled. its an older store.
author: Cindy L.

description:
We love this place.  Enough said.

It is clean, quick and quiet.  The food is delicious & they do take out :)
author: Kyla G.

description:
I always go to the neighborhood with friends and family but always just go to the restaurants across the street or up the block. Tonight, when my hubby decided to go to Dumpling House, we found a spot in front of Little Beijing. I checked out the menu and found the dishes not expensive.

DH said that he has been there many years ago but had not come back for a while. We finally gave it a try and ordered a few dishes.

The onion pancake is great, not thin like in many other restaurants. It appeared and tasted freshly made.

The crispy chicken wings were freshly cooked, tasty but I would prefer it not that sweet. I like salt and pepper way instead but it was a good dish.

Cold chicken noodles were good too, spicy the way I like. The peanut sauce tasted pretty delicious. The noodles were not wrapped with sticky sauce but absorbed the taste of the peanut spicy sauce.

The 2 free appetizers - sour pickles and boiled peanuts were VERY VERY delicious. I was tempted to ask for an extra plate of each.

Definitely, we will come back with the family and friends. For a meal of the above 3 dishes, we paid $20 (including tax and tips) which is pretty decent.
author: Roserrele W.

description: Always a great choice. ORDER THE GREEN ONION PANCAKE. Always great service and generous portions.
author: Daniel S.

description:
I use to go often and ejoyed the food, however the place has just become way too dirty and when I was eating my beef chow fun the other day I found a cigarette filter in it. I'm never going back.  I always overlooked the poor attitude of the lady that runs the show because the food was so good,  But the place is a health
Hazard.  Dirty Dirty Dirty.
author: R P.

description:
It's a hole in the wall kind of place. There are no fancy decorations, flies sometimes buzzing around your head, the waiters are sloppy and unclean looking, but the food is good.

For ABCs like me who can't read Chinese well, order the Chinese chives pancake - not the thin scallion pancake. In English it reads almost the same. This version is like a hot pocket made of a dumpling wrapper and it's stuffed with egg, chives, and some other tasty bits. Mix some soy sauce vinegar with chili sauce for a great dipping sauce. Both the beef noodle soup and the spicy seafood noodle soup here are wonderful and they really compliment this SF climate. 

All in all, great place for a light satisfying lunch or dinner. I'll be back for a third time!
author: Dennis P.

description:
I used to come here as a little kid with my family and it seemed so much bigger... but I guess that's cause I was a kid. Came back for the first time in years and the place was pretty small. Fits a few tables inside. Their not cheap with their napkins though.. so kudos to them for the first asian restaurant that gave my table a "STACK" (yes you read right) of napkins! Now onto the food.

They gave free green onion pancakes... which was alright, but it was just luke warm and there was no dipping sauce. The dipping sauce would have given it the little push to make it really good. They give you free pickled cabbage and peanuts too. The peanuts are marinated and taste pretty good... however one of the peanuts that my brother broke into had a maggot in it... was kind of gross. Can't blame them I guess since it's not like you can was the inside of the shell. We ordered the spinach tofu soup which was pretty good... expected it to be pretty boring but not bad at all. We got the chive and egg pancake as well... that I really didn't care for. Was kind of too wet for me since every bite, some of the juice was leaking out... and it was kind of bland. Got the lettuce wrap with chicken... it was decent but they should shake the water off the lettuce more since water was literally dripping down my arm with every bite... but I guess that shows that they at least rinsed it clean... so oh well? We also ordered the hunan chicken, some vegetable dish with sugar snap peas, and a beef dish that I forgot. Nothing really stood out to me but nothing was disgusting either. Just not memorable but everything was pretty greasy though... which is expected usually when you're eating out... but it was a little bit too greasy for my liking. 

Service here is okay... the older guy is more on top of things. The younger worker seems kind of lost half the time and kept delivering the wrong items to the wrong table. Overall the food was okay... I probably won't go out of my way just to eat here though.
author: Johnson S.

description:
The only thing good here is their Dan Dan Mein and Onion Pancake, everything else was just ehh.

I went around 7pm, DINNER TIME, and this place didn't have many people. What is up with that????? Somehow I expected more people, because a friend said they had great food here. Does great food not equal lots of customers? hmm...
author: Kylie L.

description:
Based on a number of recommendations here, we ordered the green onion pancake, fried vegetarian curry cakes, hot an sour soup, and family tofu.

The guy taking our order we nice, patient, and courteous. We were told the delivery would be about 25 minutes.

(insert waiting song here)

The green onion pancakes were delicious. Seems it could use a dipping sauce, but it wasn't a biggy. The curry cakes were alright. Not sure if I would get them again, but they were not bad. Worth a try once at least.

As for the main dishes, the hot and sour soup was really good, but not the best I've ever had--although we will order it again. The family tofu was a lot better the next day, cold. But it wasn't terrible either. I think next time we will try a different vegetarian main dish. (If anyone has recommendations, please message me!)

So all in all, we were happy with our dinner and Little Beijing Restaurant. The delivery was fast and the food was hot and plentiful. Having delicious leftovers for a few extra was icing on the cake... err, rice-cake.
author: K. C.

description:
minus one star for cleanliness. 

the food is delicious, especially their dumplings, dry fried chicken wings, and noodles. this is our alternative to the always busy san tung. their food is definitely comparable, and pricing competitive.
author: Char L.

description: When my favorite Chinese restaurant closed right next door i was heartbroken and thought i would try my luck at Little Beijing. As we SF residents know all too well, there is the best AND the worst Chinese in San Francisco so I am always skeptical of trying new places without a recommendation or a Yelp review pointing me in the right direction. Once we sat down we watched 3 other Chinese families be seated and served before us. I don't want to mention the weighted term racist, but if you are not asian, some places in asian districts do tend to treat you differently. After 20 minutes we finally were able to give our orders. Everything except the crab cakes and the soup was very mediocre if not less than average. The chow mein was terrible. The crab cakes, however, were some of the best I have ever had! Now I only return to get to go orders of crab cakes every so often.
author: Hilary Z.

description:
I almost don't want to write a review because the last thing I want is for this place to become famous and swamped with people! This is hands down the best chinese food I've ever had. The food is spicy! Not what all other asian restaurants seem to call spicy either. The chicken is white meat and if you bite into it- you can look at it and actually see meat! Inconceivable! The garlic wings are like a glorious twist on general chicken that are more addicting than buffalo wings and just as spicy. The best crab and cheese wontons, the best rolling lettuce chicken and Mongolian beef. I could just continue to rave. The restaurant is a little dingy and could use some music or something, but they do takeout and deliver if you order over $20, and after that you start to get free food. I've felt disappointed and grossed out when i've ordered from any other chinese restaurant, the 2 years I've lived here since my first arrival at this establishment. The servers are always so pleased to see you and they're positive attitude consistantly improves my mood. 
I adore them. Try'em out. The dishes I've mentioned will change your life. The hot and sour soup will clear out your sinuses for 3 days. 
Love'em.
author: Lara E.

description: New fave spot for chinese food. Great spot. Gen Cho's chicken is really delish.
author: Nicole H.

description: I really enjoyed the green onion pancakes and the smoked tea chicken. The Korean chicken wings were pretty good too! This is definitely not a fancy place but it is reasonable and fulfilling!
author: SJ L.

description:
This is a great place for affordable but tasty food with really friendly service. We found this place because we really wanted to go to the dessert place around the corner afterwards (but needed a real meal before).

I ordered the Hunan Meatless Chicken, which I thought would come with those actual fake meat stuff but it was actually just the "baked" tofu, but I liked it anyway. It was flavorful and spicy. However, I did not like their profuse use of celery.

The waiter guy was this older dude, whose friendliness was extremely refreshing (i just lived in Europe for a year).
author: Ëmily Y.

description: This is your run of the mill family ran restaurant.  There is nothing really spectacular about the place.  The food is average.  We ordered the egg soup and the small could feed our party of 4 so that was a good deal.  It was a little bland but better than too salty.  They give you pickled cabbage and salty peanuts as appetizers.  We also ordered the general tsai chicken, mongolian beef, and bok choy with mushrooms.  The general tsai was too saucy but other than that it was okay.  The mongolian beef was pretty good but was too spicy for me to eat but my family enjoyed it.  The bok choy with mushroom was bland and surprisingly the worse dish there.  I wonder how the vegetarian dishes are there but probably won't try it since there are so many other restaurants in SF to try!
author: Eating And Living Well U.

description:
A thank you to my fellow Yelpers for steering me here.  A solid 3.5 stars good but not spectacular.

I went for the Hot & Sour Soup.  Not too hot though and I'm no spicy fiend.

Green Onion pancakes.  Definitley worth the order

Pork,Shrimp and Chive dumplings.  Really good.

Tea was delicious

Place is a hole in the wall and not much for decor but I look for food quality and not fancy wall hangings.  Seemed like a mix of families and neighborhood people in for lunch with young and old alike.  

Plenty of Chinese style restaurants on this street to try if you're not feeling the vibe.

My server was attentive and I didn't have any angry old lady yelling at me.  

Left full and happy.  See you soon Little Beijing
author: Howard R.

description: Awesomely huge potstickers that were delicious! I will be back to try to the spicy stuff!
author: Jen D.

description: Oh how much I crave their cuisine when I am away from the city! Don't ever change chefs or close. Might be nice to repaint every now and then, though :)
author: Anna N.

description:
I haven't been here for 5 years and I wonder if the chef changed (or maybe just today?) I'll just comment on 2 dishes:

My favorite dish here used to be Schechuan eggplant. It has too much garlic and the skin not as crisp as before. Unfortunately I will go elsewhere for this dish now.

I recently tried General Tsao's chicken, which is a variation of sweet and sour pork. The idea is that it combines 4 flavors: sweet, salty, sour, and spicy. At Little Beijing, they almost have it right- it could use a little more vinegar. I love how crispy it is though. This dish might bring me back, since only select chinese restaurants make this specialty.

Each dish is ~$7 for dinner, slightly more expensive than my preferred Chinese restaurant Jumbo (~$5-6/dish) I'd recommend coming here if you want a more mandarin style of cooking. Jumbo, in contrast, is more Southern/Cantonese.
author: Lina C.

description: a warning first...spicy little firecracker meals...hot is definitely hot!...little beijing...small, aged and casual...friendly service and finding comfort...a small set combination dinner from menu...an extra pancake and dish...starting with hot and sour soup...adding vinegar and finding a little fly inside...quick bottle replacement with no fly...self not caring about rough start...main delivered and finding portions quite large...pancakes quite the toasty crisp...soysauce dip and bite...trying the spicy chicken and yowza!...tongue numbing spice lingering deep inside...mouthful of rice and trying again...spicy heat multiplying from each bite...sweating just writing this...so spicy, but so good...mouth burning...no more after....meal cheap!...portions huge!...but, divey chinese....
author: Hen A.

description: Service is okay. Foods ok too. I like their spicy fish fillet(i think its the dish name maybe?)
author: Vicky Z.

description:
Little Beijing is my go to place in the sunset when I'm craving soup and something spicy.  Their hot and sour soup is very good. They get the amount of spice and sourness just right and I like that they put a good amount of tofu in.  Their sub gum noodle soup is also very very good.  I love the spicy soup and the texture of their noodles. This soup is also full of seafood (shrimp, fish, squid) and veggies.  Their dumplings are also good in addition to their green onion pancake.  I've tried some of their other dishes but nothing else really stands out.  

Service can be a little slow but nothing beats the price of the food here.  The noodle soup above is only $6.95 and the portion size is pretty big.
author: Amelia L.

description:
I came here on a Saturday evening because Google Maps had mistakenly placed me at a dumpling SUPPLY restaurant instead of an actual dumpling restaurant. Since we were starving, we wandered up the street to Little Beijing. It was empty when we strolled in at 6:30pm, save for one large Chinese family at a round table.

I was a bit sketched out at first.. This would either be a major win or major fail. Yelp quickly gave me some tips (get the waitress' attention, order anything that says "house special" next to it). What I got:

- Shrimp, pork and leek dumplings. They dumplings themselves were fine and tasty, but they showed up barely above lukewarm. Very odd. Still edible since we were starving.
- Friend ordered the Monglian beef. Tasted fine. Bowl of rice was extra.
- I got the house special Shanghai style fried noodles, my favorite dish in the world. The noodles were fine, albeit a bit salty, the spinach was fine.. But I only found a few meager scraps of pork in the dish :(

So I probably would never come back here again.
author: Wendy T.

description:
If I want cheap and good Beijing food, I would come to Little Beijing. Remember, this is a Chinese restaurant and if you want good customer service then this is not the place for you. The food here is quite good in comparison with the low price. The green onion pancake is crispy and thick. The beef with asparagus is tender and tasty. The pork dumplings here are not bad. I really like the spicy stirred fried dumplings here taste like dumplings in gravy (Taiwanese style.) The Mu Shu chicken here is not bad really tasty but very few chicken pieces so if one is a meat lover this is not the dish for you. 

Pricing here is really good: one onion pancake, one asparagus and beef and Mu Shu chicken costs about $22.00 including tax.
author: Allison H.

description:
Decided to check this place out, for the Sichuan dishes.  Friendly service.  It's above average, but nothing special.

Sichuan fish filet was good. Tasty and spicy.  Nowhere close to the complexity and depth of flavor of comparable dishes at Dong Bei Mama though.

Tried their vegetarian Hunan Chicken (fake meat).  Also very tasty, but nothing fantastic.

Green onion pancackes really are excellent, if you like them thick, chewy and doughy, rather than thin and crispy.  Kind of like the Chicago Deep Dish of Green Onion Pancackes (you can see it just a little in the photo someone attached, but they really are quite thick)

I'd eat here again if I was in the neighborhood looking for a place to eat, but I wouldn't make a special trip.
author: Ritch G.

description:
You know, I was going to recommend their excellent green onion pancake, hot and sour soup, ci fan tuan (glutinous rice wrapped around a long Chinese donut with pork sung) and a few other dishes.

What gives? The craptastic service, way below average for your Chinese neighborhood spot. The waiter is really nice but the manager lady has issues. She yelled at the waiter in front of the patrons the last time we were here a month ago. It's nice she treats her regulars with care but she treats others with indifference, plonking dishes down on the table, etc. Whatever - I was willing to overlook that because the food is pretty good.

My mom and I just left the restaurant 30 mins ago. As we were walking out the door, she calls out to us, asking us in Mandarin for her tip. OMGWTF! You DO NOT ask people for a effing tip. In our defense: we left a tip but we had quite a few dishes on the table so it wasn't visible when she brought us our boxes.

What a low-class ill-mannered woman.
author: Manda W.

description:
I used to work a block away from this place, and of all the Chinese cuisine choices in the area, this was my favorite. Although the ownership has changed in recent times, the food remains practically the same. Don't let the Beijing name fool you. The fare here is not all Northern Chinese, but rather more of a hodge podge of various cuisines from around the "Middle Kingdom."

They also have their own take on "Americanized" Chinese food such as General Chao's chicken and Mongolian beef, and do quite a great job with it. For those who crave something more authentic, they have practically everything covered. There is nothing rare or unique - just your basic dishes you can find anywhere else - but the chefs here tend not to use too much sauce or salt, so you don't feel all bloated when you are finished.

Unlike many establishments in the Sunset, non-Chinese are welcome here as far as I can see. Obviously, I wouldn't know first hand, but from my observation, the staff here treats everyone as equals. Also, typical of Chinese restaurants, there is a "secret" menu written in Chinese on the wall, but if you do not understand, the waiter will be glad to translate for you, instead of telling you that  "You wouldn't like it."

This is not a high class restaurant, nor does it try to be. It's just a little dive for a quick bite if you happen to be in the area. Parking can be a hassle in the daytime (all metered), but if you drive a bit off into the residential area, there should some open spaces.
author: Eric W.

description:
I love the food here, especially the onion pancake. I always order the onion pancake when Im here, this is my second favorite after Taste of Formosa...

Im not going to get into details about what type of food I ordered and what they had in it. why? well cause I cant remember. It was pretty much a blur. One thing I do know is that my grandparents and mom and aunts and...i guess my family in general likes to eat here too. And the lady is always oh so nice~ I guess it pays to speak mandarin haha.

The restaurant itself is not that big and its not fancy shmancy. Just come in sit down order and eat~ o yea and its not that pricey either ^____^
author: phillip w.

description: Although the way they prepared or presented the entrees is a bit different, that's not to say I didn't enjoy the food overall. The green onion pancake appetizers were denser like bread than I had expected and not as flaky. The egg foo young was like a huge airy frittata filled with large pieces of meat (I chose barbecue pork) and vegetables (bok choy, broccoli, carrots) that were piled on top. The thinly sliced fatty sichuan beef was actually served in a bowl of spicy soup. The spicy salty spareribs didn't have a crispy outer coating but was dusted/powdered with garlic. Lastly, found bits of pork? (not too sure) at the bottom of the bowl of an average sichuan dan dan mein.
author: Cliff W.

description:
I've been here about 4 times over the span of 3 years and the 4th time, which was this past weekend would be the last time I'll ever step foot into this place.

This place is DIRTY - and you see flies flying around your food (kinda gross). If you have OCD, stay away from this place.

I've had their wide array of food there. In fact, I've even tried their weekend breakfast special, which by far can't compare to anything close to what I can get in LA or places in the south bay.

I've had their beef noodle soup twice: the first time was good that's why I ordered it again but this time the soup tasted like soysauce soup. It was nasty!!! 

I think the only item I would even recommend at this place is their crispy onion pancake which you know they probably used a lot of shortening to make it (aka trans fat!!!).

The male waiter (I think he is the husband) is a really nice guy but I can't say the same about his wife. Last time when my mom ask for a spoon, she asked "what do you need a spoon?" OMG!!!
author: Alice L.

description:
I ended up here with Ed M for brunch. We ended up getting the green onion pancakes (along with wonton noodle soup, this is my other barometer to see if a Chinese restaurant is worthy), shrimp, pork and chive dumplings, and two noodle dishes. 

The bill came out to only $20 (SCORE!) and we were quite full. 

Me: There's something different about this fortune cookie...
Ed M: What? 
Me: I don't know. (tastes fortune cookie some more) Oh, I've got it!
Ed M: WHAT?!?
Me: It's vanilla flavored!
Ed M: OOOH!

My mother would approve.
author: Patrick L.

description:
The food here was unmemorable, honestly. We got the green onion pancakes, the pork dumplings, the shirmp, pork and chives dumplings, the chicken scrambled tofu, szechuan dan dan mein, curry chicken, beef chow fun, and beef friend rice.

Service was slightly pushy. They were open at 3:00 for lunch which was surprising and convenient; however, they kept trying to get us to order more implying that we hadn't ordered enough.
author: Carolyn W.

description:
delicious, but food so greasy ,Always push you order more and more and I feel a bit expensive.
Anyway I like it !
author: K H H.

description:
Little Beijing is very cheap- unfortunately the quality of the food is correlated somewhat to the cheapness.

The green onion pancake is too thick and do not have enough onion. The dish might as well be called fried dough. The dan dan mien is neither Szichuan or Taiwanese style. The dish that I like the most is probably the spicy fish in chili oil. 

A good place for big group but not the best place to get good chinese food.
author: Fred F.

description: I'm happy I found this place. Spicy green beans are amazing! Flavorful crispy, just perfect. Friese rice was great and the orange chicken awesome! I really loved all I order. I found my new fav Chinese takeout .
author: Karen P.

description:
Cheap and easy!

Went there on a Friday night with a big group (16 people) and they handled us fine.  The bill came out to a tad less than $10 per person!

Food's northern Chinese kind of stuff: noodles (the black bean paste and dan dan mein were simple, yet good), green onion pancake (it's a thicker, fried version, pretty good), and other spicy/fried things.  Slightly greasy, but manageable and overall tasty.  Proportions pretty good as well.

Atmosphere: small restaurant with 2 waiters and ~10 tables (small, medium, & large sized) in a semi-quiet part of Sunset.  Has a mixed crowd: young, old, Asian, non-Asian, families, groups of friends, etc.  It can get a little loud when the restaurant has a lot of people, but it's friendly.  Decorated regularly, not that special.  One restroom all the way in the back.  A little crowded to get to it, but overall clean.

Service: the waiters are Chinese but can understand English enough for business.  Food came at a steady pace and got us everything we asked for.
author: Jason K.

description:
My cousin successfully convinced me to try this out on a Saturday night instead of one of the more frou-frou restaurants on the Chronicle's top 100 list, and it was good.  

Decor-wise, not much to talk about.    Your standard hole in the wall Chinese restaurant with typical homely, not-so-sparkling-clean interior.    In response to some of the other reviews, not all Chinese restaurants have figured out or have the money to do a wonderful interior decorating job, so it can't be helped. 

We ordered a bunch of things, I don't have all the proper names since I let my cousin do the ordering.   The was a sticky rice roll with a "fried stick usually reserved for jook" embedded in the middle, along with that deep fried fish stuff that's commonly added to jook.   Good stuff...I'm a big fan of rice balls of any sort, this was a new variation.    

Another plate was the popular green onion bread.    It's tasty, but I didn't care for the flakey texture.    I prefer the chewy, stretchy variety or the thick, bread-like green onion bread served at Fatima in San Jose. 

General Chau's chicken...regardless of whether or not it's a westernized Chinese dish, it was yummy and done right (unlike the cheap, unpalatable fare that one will find at nasty $1 Chinese express  food places).

The pork dumplings were nothing to really write home about.   I've had better.  

Lastly, there was a spicy noodle mixed with seafood.     Just hot enough to have zest and make one's nose run (for the typical person who eats out), but not hot enough to require multiple glasses of water.  
Best dish of the evening.  

Service  was attentive...just this one girl, and a few other patrons in the restaurant.   

The total bill ended up being a $15 split with leftovers to spare.    We both left the place completely stuffed and contented.     Good value.
author: Jason C.

description:
At the top of the menu it says they highly recommend the house specials, so we ordered a couple that were, the pork dumplings and the green onion pancake, and a couple that weren't, the mapo tofu and the Beijing string beans.  

I liked the pancake, it was thick and doughy and crispy on the outside.  The dumplings were good, it seemed like everyone in the place ordered them, but they weren't the best ever.  The mapo tofu warmed me up on a cold day and the string beans were garlicky and slightly sweet-very tasty.

3.5 stars, it was decent and not that expensive, food and service could use a little improvement though.
author: Mike U.

description:
I've been away from SF for the past 2 years, but recently came home for a visit when my sweet mother had a surprise in store for me.  A chinese restaurant OTHER THAN SAN TUNG.  AMEN!  Sick of their shitty service anyway...although no one can beat their dried fried chicken wings...Ooops, going off on a tangent here...back to Little Beijing.

The food is excellent here.  We were the first ones to be seated at 5:30 on Sunday night and what do you know?  NO WAIT!  We ordered the green onion pancakes (which, if you order, don't order too many other side dishes b/c these little puppies  will fill you up QUICKLY).  The fried pork spare ribs were AMAZING.  I have NO idea what the cooks seasoned this delectable dish with, but whatever it was, it made me dream about it in my sleep.  It was that f****** good & I'm not "usually into fried pork spare ribs."  The spicy seafood soup was good.  But I have to admit, San Tung is better.  

Honestly, I can't recall the other dishes, but I know we ordered a lot for 5 people & seriously, after finishing the green onion pancakes & fried pork spare ribs, nothing else mattered.  

They don't speak English very well, but since I went with a Mandarin speaking friend, it was ok.  I think the owner speaks some English b/c I noticed quite a few non-Chinese families in the restaurant & she was quite friendly to them, too.  Parking is a breeze b/c Noriega doesn't have the "reputation" of Irving..not yet, anyway.  We'll see how long that lasts.
author: Christie X.

description:
Their hot&sour soup is really good!!!!!! (mostly why we keep ordering, not to say that the other food is mediocre) 

Their prices are really resonable, portions are very good. 

Friendly employees, no complaints there.

Overall it's a great place to get take-out!
author: Sarah T.

description:
"Meatless" friggin' battered "no-fu!", foiled and soiled like a dumpster in front of a rhinoplasty festival.
I thought i was an accidental archaeologist by uncovering another spot with numerous "meatless morsels with grease varietals", and i would be sorta correct. The general's liquid performed it's standardized duty, but the bobbing, encrusted silken rhombuses listlessly reactivated my tastebuds for prolly a minute.  

Harangue-o-tang- DANNNNGG!!!
author: Christopher J.

description:
General Tso's Chicken, that's all you gotta order cuz its money right there and the mongolian beef.  I dont' remember anything else standing out from a meal there but that's enough to make you enjoy the place.  

It's small and tucked away in the little restaurant area on Noriega.  They also have lunch specials which gets you a meal for about $6-7 dollars.  Cool huh?
author: Vincent K.

description:
I've been here once before and I fell in love w/their dumplings and hand pulled noodles.  Their rice cakes were nothing to brag about--they were kinda bland, even though i POURED TONS of vinegar for some kind of flavor.

I went back a second time a few days ago with the hubby and their tomato beef chow mein blew me away (as well as their dumplings!). Yummmmmy!  

P.S. I love their pickled cabbage...delish..
author: Jocelyn W.

description:
"So babe, this is going to be our Chinese place, right?" said my boyfriend after we finished our first dinner there.  The following week, we came to the area and toyed with the idea of going back, but we went to another place instead.  A decision that we regretted dearly.  So the following week we went back again.  

Make sure you try the items that is marked "House Special."  They do not disappoint.  The green onion pancakes are ah-mays-zing!  And the price is right.  Service may seem cold, but we weren't expecting much from a Chinese restaurant, and you shouldn't too.  Unless of course you're paying upwards $30/person.  

The place is small but never full.  So go before it becomes too popular!  Parking in the area is super easy.  And then if you get too full afterwards, go to Turtle Hill and burn off the calories by climbing the stairs.
author: Yohanna B.

description: Not bad, but probably wouldn't get take out here from again. It's cheap, but the quality is mediocre. I got the General Cho's pork, beef chow fun, and green onion pancakes. Everything tasted okay. It definitely wasn't bad, it just wasn't great. Portion size is good, so that's a plus. I got take out so I can't comment on the service. Probably worth a try if you live in the neighborhood, but don't go out of your way to eat here.
author: Call Me Z.

description: I like this place because the price for dumplings and small dishes like chicken wings are all reasonably priced. The green onion pancakes here are pretty big and not a lot of flour used with a good mix of green onions to add enough flavor for me to order it almost all the time I go here. The food is good and I have made this place one of the regular restaurants that I eat at. The only reason why I dont give this place 5 stars is because some of the food is the same at other restaurants, but not enough for me not to like the food. I would definitely recommend this place to people.
author: robin b.

description:
