Good place to grab a quick bite. Due to the *quiet* neighborhood and a lack of decor on the outside, there shouldn't be any waits for a table.

Quality of food is surprisingly good... and given the price... good becomes VERY good. We had tons for 20 bones.

Here's the challenge, if you can get the lady who works there to crack a smile THREE times. PM me and I'll buy you dinner there.
author: Stanley L.

description: Very good! Their $10 a person combos are more food than we could eat and it was good food too. I'd go again for sure!
author: Chris I.

description: General chicken and twice cook pork both are a MUST TRY.... Also our favorite dish is DAN DAN MIEN..
author: Julia S.

description:
Dan Dan Mien delicious!! =) It's like a peanut sauce noodle .. mmMm spicy~ The chicken fried rice is good too andd so is the hot and sour soup ... Green onion pancake is yummy but it's kind of oily and thick.

Nothing to complain about so far, I've only ate at the restaurant once, and all the other times to-go.
author: Allyson L.

description:
My parents & I are regulars. I like the food here, and the lady is very nice. She speaks Mandarin to my parents, and I don't understand. She speaks English also but never speaks it to us. I guess she assumes that I speak Mandarin as well? Oh well.

They make one of the best Hot & Sour Soups I've ever had in my life! Love it! We always compare this restaurant with San Tung. They have similar styles, but Little Beijing is more low key. Not as crowded and popular as San Tung. Whenever we want this kind of food, we usually come here instead because we never have to wait. 

5 stars for Little Beijing!
author: Steph C.

description:
This is probably one of my favorite chinese food places to go and eat. I love their hot and sour soup more than anything. Everything else is done really well, i have ye to find a dish i dont like. my dad and i go here pretty often.

The only thing i dont like about this place is the lady that waitresses/hosts. she is so angry and scary all the time. when i go with my dad, we are usually the one caucasian people in there, and i dont know if it's because of that, but she never comes over to us to take our order unless we flag her down. we basically get no service unless we signal to her, and when we do that she looks like she's going to shoot us for doing so. 

so overall, food is awesome, but watch out for the crabby lady. i see her one day snapping and going on a killing rampage, just fyi
author: Casey Z.

description: the food is so dirty i cant even handle the food! i ordered Pork but she gave me chicken, and i was like what the hell! After the Pork came it wasnt even fresh at all! when i ordered water she even checked my ID i was like wtf!! dont go at all it is super stupid
author: Milo L.

description:
The following dishes are COMPLETELY mediocre:

General Tsos Chix: Too much batter, chewy, sauce is 6/10. Add it all up, not worth ordering. 

Green Onion Pancake: Everyone reviewing says this is really good. So I ordered it. It's just kind of greasy and bland. Really needs some sort of sauce/not to exist

Chive, Pork, and something dumpling: Fine. Kinda smells like gym socks.

Combo Chow Mein: Greasy; prety much tasteless. 

Now that I've written it out, i think a pattern might be emerging...

Agruably, I didn't order the whole menu to try.

Not so arguably, I'd rather light a $50 bill on fire and put needles in my eyes than order the whole menu to try.
author: Jake R.

description: Little Beijing Restaurant of Noriega is a pretty good restaurant. The place may look small but they make the food pretty good and tasty and this place is not to expensive.
author: William B.

description:
I have been coming to this hole in the wall for several years. The owners have changed but my favorite dish has not. The Salt and Pepper prawns here are the best (in my little world). They are not too soggy or under spiced. I normally don't eat the heads and tails like the rest of my motherland born family, but at this place I will. I just can't get enough. 

I also love the wet peanuts and pickled vegetables you get pre-meal. I often drag my cousins who can read Chinese here so I can order off the wall posted specials with confidence. They recently changed their fortune cookie brand and it's not the greatest, but who needs a cookie when Polly Ann's is down the street (not walkable, but whatever)
author: Alia D.

description:
I've been coming to this establishment for years now. Though the quality of Little Beijing's food dropped in the last few years due to ownership changes, I am pleased that the restaurant went back to its original owner and food quality has gone up. 

Excellent prices and fast service. Try the ja jerng mein, gao choy dumplings, wontons with spicy sauce on the side, beef noodle soup, and dun dahn mein.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
Little Beijing is my family's favorite place for takeout, which we've had so many times it feels like home cooking.  The dishes are pretty consistent in the way of flavor and  their generous portions.

Family favorites include:

Green Onion Pancakes
Spicy Won Ton
Won Ton Soup (great when you're sick)
General Cho's Chicken
Szechwan Eggplant
author: Elyn S.

description:
Great potstickers
Great giant potsticker made of chives
Great pig ear
Great jia jiang mien

I actually love this place, and the mamacita calling the shots is a straight gangster dripping with sarcasm (at least in Chinese she is).  Quite beautiful too for a women her age...

Oh yeah, you can call ahead to get your order started.
And don't, by any means, close the door if she's propped it open.  She will ask you "Why did you close the door, it's hot in the kitchen."

Best kept secret on Noriega.  Way less greasy than Old Mandarin (Lao Beijing) on (edit: 11/27) Vicente.
author: D. T.

description:
Today I came here for lunch. Time was about 1 something in the afternoon. They were pretty much pack. Not hard since they have about 10 tables or so. The food took a while because there was only two waiters and I believe there's only one cook. 

I think it's a family business with the mom/wife working in the kitchen only and the father and son working the front of the restaurant.

It took a while before we got tea. It took another couple of minutes before our order was taken. It took about another 5-10 minutes before our order came. 

Overall lunch was as expected. Nothing fancy. The eggplant that I ordered wasn't even that spicy. Pick and choose your time to go here. Also, if you're going to have a large party for lunch call ahead and make sure they can accommodate you. When I was partly eating lunch a party of 14 walked in.
author: Jen C.

description:
Saw the neon pink and yellow sign and figured, 'okay, this place will not disappoint.' and sure enough, it was amazing. great little random find on noriega while simply perusing the neighborhood for a chinese bite. Being the pescatarian i am, im always searching for nice little chinese places that dont flood their menus with common meat dishes like kung pao chicken, mongolian beef, and so forth. 

i ordered general tsao's meatless chicken (tofu substituted for chicken) and it was drool-worthy. while at times i dislike it when sauces overpower a dish, the sauce teamed up with the crispiness of the tofu made a stomach-smiling duo. inexpensive, tasty and filling--great repeat visit restaurant.
author: Angeline L.

description:
Decent delivery.  What can I say - it's basic Chinese food.  It isn't fabulous - but it is far from bad.  The hot stuff does taste like they went a little wild with the hot oil rather than chili peppers, but it's definitely yummy.

The delivery guy was extremely nice, as were the folks on the phone when I placed my order.

I wish I could give them a 3.5, but since I can't, I'll give them a 4 since everything tasted good.  

Just a note to give you full disclosure when it comes to Chinese food for me - part of my problem is that I am on a constant search for a replacement for the late great Golden City Restaurant that used to be on Irving.  Oh Princess Prawns, where art thou!  If anyone knows where these people went, please let me know - I will sell my soul for the recipes that graced their menu.  Even the broccolli beef was like none I had ever tasted anywhere else.  Oh why must this world be so cruel???
author: Luba M.

description:
Best to stick to the house specials when ordering.  Great green onion pancakes, hot and sour soup, Sichuan beef (nice and hot), and Beijing string beans.  The Beijing Sweet and Sour pork was tender, but nothing special.  The "W &H" stands for wife and husband, which is a traditional dish served cold made with beef and stomach, and I wasn't crazy about it.  We ordered the fried chicken wings with the General Cho's sauce on them, and they were quite spicy and really good -- better than San Tung's.  

The owner runs the place herself, which must be what keeps the quality so high.  And it is very reasonably priced, given its quality and authenticity.
author: Adam Z.

description: The best hot and sour soup I have eaten...vegetarians, this is a great place.  Had the vegetarian hot and sour soup, still thinking about it.  The General Cho's meatless chicken was delicious (could use some jalapenos), the green beans were perfectly cooked with a tasty sauce.  The mushu vegetables were delicious but even better, the pancakes were thick and I believe made in-house.  Price is good too.  So very glad that it's in my neighborhood.
author: Maria J.

description:
noriega street between 19th ave and 30th ave has more chinese restaurants per block than any street in the nation. okay, that may not be 100% true, but it's not far from the truth.

so how does one choose which chinese place to go to? you gotta try em all!

well little beijing was tried, and i liked it. i suggest the shanghai noodles and the salt and pepper prawns. but you gotta be willing to eat the heads.
author: Ameer N.

description:
I found myself in this restaurant once again for a family dinner. The decor is pretty bland (and pink), but the food was good and service quick! 

The hostess was great in reading into what we wanted, telling us for some of the dishes we tried to order were not good for our group and to order something else instead. Her suggestions was awesome and delicious.
author: R H.

description:
My friend and I decided to try out this place for our Friday dinner and the visit here will be our (or at least my) last. The food here wasn't that great. I ordered the lemon chicken and it was basically fried chicken in way too much lemon sauce. My friend ordered the onion pancakes and the fried shrimp appetizers. My friend said the shrimp had no taste, not even a seasoning. The onion pancakes were good though. I didn't like how they charged extra for rice. Most Chinese restaurants already give you rice with your dish.
The service here only added to the horrible experience. It was terrible. Yes, the lady is a *****. She seemed to treat regulars nice while she completely ignored the others. There was one instance where she tossed a dirty rag onto the table next to us, right over my head, and it almost nailed me. No tip for her. The waiter didn't seem to know who ordered what and had to continuously ask the lady for help. I ordered a Coke and it never came to me until after I asked them about it.
Do you have free time to kill or like waiting in restaurants? This place is perfect for you. It took them about 40 minutes to get our order and then serve us our order. A family who came in a little after us got up and left because they were sitting there for 20 minutes without any service. Some guy PICKING UP his food-to-go was waiting ten minutes until someone finally helped him.
I think I know why this place is empty most of the time. Everyone got up and left because they had to wait forever for service.

Bottomline: Don't go here. There are lots of other Chinese restaurants around the neighborhood with better service and food.
author: Austin C.

description:
went there once, was a Saturday nite, been waiting long for the table, that cool with me, as i always said, no one want to go to a empty restaurants, finial we get our table, everything was good until the last 10 min. we had the hot pot, waitress turn the pot off before ask us " are you finish" ...hello~ ....we still eating, that fine we let it go, then another waiter come by with the waitress clean up the table, is total clean up even the tea pot and cup...hello~....we still sitting at the table......i understand you guys rush to turn over table, but ......not that kind of rush.......i can wait for a table....other people can wait as well~~
round it up....one star....won't be back~!
author: David D.

description: I've been here a few times and enjoy the dumplings, beef noodle soup, and shanghaiese noodles (although disappointingly, this last one barely had any meat in it the last time I went).  Super cheap as well.  I was displeased with service this most recent time - it felt like it took FOREVER for each plate to come out.  They seemed to serve them in courses, which, hello, is not what I come to Chinese restaurants for.  But in any case, this is one of my parents' faves so I will be back.
author: Melinda C.

description: Cheap food, cheap taste. Beef chow fun, beef fried rice, and mongolian beef are all pretty simple meals to make too. Also, the fried chicken wings are a little too fried. When we got them, they were charred.
author: Jonathan C.

description: I've never been to the actual restaurant because we always just order it to go, but the service is always extremely fast, and the staff is very friendly. The delivery man carries change for twenty dollar bills on him. The prices are great, and the food is plentiful, and comes with a complimentary salad. (and the food tastes fantastic).
author: Leeya S.

description: Price is really decent.  We ordered about 12 dishes and the total came up to be around $120 including tips.  Each dish cost around $6-$8.   Not too bad if you ask me.  The food was delicious.  This was the first spot that doesnt drizzle a gallon of mayo on their walnut prawns.  Instead they put the mayo on the side.  I hate when certain places drown the shrimp with mayo.  Ewww... Must get the salt and pepper pork.  So delicious.  Not too greasy, not a lot of bones... this is my kind of dish.  This is a good place to check out.
author: Mimi S.

description: Give this place a try. Their house specials, including their spicy wantons are excellent. Their food has a lot of flavor and is very reasonably priced.
author: Scott W.

description:
wow, so many negative comments about the owner lady *itch. and i couldn't agree more. part of being the restaurant business is about hospitatlity and service (a BIG part). no matter how delicious your food is, no one wants to go back to a place that provides poor service. 

the dan dan mein is pretty good. it's the only thing i've tried on the menu.
author: Diana T.

description: I'm not a big fan of sunset/richmond but I decided to come with my best friend here since I was having a bad day and needed some variety. The waiter walked came over with the menu he started speaking to me in Mandarin, we established that both him and I were Taiwanese so he started to make fun of my "American" best friend hehe, waiters' a funny guy, the food was decent and we even got a some free dessert at the end =) Inexpensive with tons of left over =)
author: Tiff W.

description: The food is ok, but the lady manager/waitress person is a bitch! That's the only reason I would never go back. My family used to eat there when I was little, and the previous owner who worked the tables-SHE was a gem-very nice and really helpful, but, man, when she sold the business to the current manager, the place became as cold and uninviting as a witch's tit!
author: Julien N.

description: They make a decent attempt with their mock meat dishes, which they have quite a few of.  But it's not even close to touching Jasmine Tea House or Big Lantern.  Their green onion pancakes, while not as appealing as Taste of Formosa, were just as filling, though, more greasy.  Decor is nothing exciting, and service was nothing to complain about.  Best of all?  It's cheap.
author: Marsha Z.

description: I noticed during recent visits that the hated/feared owner lady has not been present.  In her place are the younger guy mentioned in my previous update and another guy waiting on the tables. I found out from the latter that the owner opened up another business and is now spending her time there instead.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: The weekend menu which includes green onion pancake and soybean drink were pretty good tasting.  The main reason I won't return is that the lady (owner?) who works there acted like she reallly didn't want our business.  (I keep checking for an opportunity to return, but she is always there with her arms folded!)  Now I go to the Peking Restaurant across the street because their food is good, their menu is similiar. and their service is very good.
author: Kim T.

description: Correct Chinese restaurant, good soups, correct  Xiao Long Bao.
author: Alex A.

description:
This is another "Mom & Pop" shop.  Their food is great and spicy.  I've been here a few times, but only with a few friends.  But one time when I came here a whole bunch of friends (7 ppl), service was slow.  there was only one waitress/busser/cashier/host...she's doing it all!
It's a good place to eat if you have time and a small party (Less than 4).  But if you're expecting a bigger party..look else where!

Food of recommendation:  
*Mongolian Beef - best tasting compared to over 20 restaurants in SF and SJ.  (My friend always order Mongolian beef.!)
*Green Onion pancakes

Word of advice...eventhough the price is reasonable, don't order too much because they're very filling!
author: Gary Y.

description:
Just to set the record straight I have never actually eaten inside the restaurant so this review is strictly for their take out. Now that that's out of the way I love this place!

This is my boyfriend and I's go to Chinese take out restaurant. We usually order the vegetable fried rice, General Tsao's chicken, the green beans beef, and the shrimp with black bean sauce, all of which are delicious. It's free delivery with a minimum of $20 and the delivery is generally quick and friendly. The same man delivers our food every time and he always has a smile on his face. It may not be the BEST chinese food I've ever had but it's pretty darn good!
author: Kristy M.

description: I don't even know how to express my disdain for this place. The both of the waiters were either idiots or didn't understand basic English. The food wasn't exactly bad, in fact some stuff was quite good, but the had some majors fails. The water they served us tasted like soap or something sweet and unnatural. We had to ask for plain tap water because it was undrinkable. They said it must be lemon... wtf?! I don't even want to know what that lemon looked like. When I ordered my food I made it very clear that it couldn't have any sesame seeds or oil in any dishes, due to my allergy. When the honey walnut shrimp came out with sesame seeds on the walnut I sent it back. So they brought it back without the walnuts. So my honey shrimp turned out to be simply fried shrimp with a little honey sauce on the side, not tossed with the shrimp like in every other Chinese restaurant, but I ate it anyway.  I assumed at this point that they had just forgotten my steamed rice, but they were so kind to bring it out when I was almost finished with my meal. While we were eating the older gentleman waiter started swatting at something with a freaking BUG ZAPPER . This is when everything really fell apart. When they brought us boxes for our leftovers the lid wouldn't fit on the soup. The young idiot waiter wouldn't help me close it and said that some of the lids don't fit so well, thats why he gave me two plastic bags. So I had a diva moment when I asked him to find a lid that worked, but srsly wtf?!  I definitely won't be coming back here, and I don't think you should either.
author: Lily P.

description: I came here just last week with a few friends . We had the spicy wontons , spicy beef , cold noodle , and eggplant .. all of which were really tasty . I like this place more than Spices . I will definitely be back here again :)
author: Eileen L.

description: This place wasn't too bad. Lived around the neighborhood and I've been here a few times for lunch. It fit 10 of my buds n me so I didn't complain. This place is family owned and got to support the locals right? Salt n Peppa Prawns, white rice, Chinese style pickled veggies and peanuts and some good ol spicy food. The blends they put together makes my taste buds tingle and the food aint so Canto greasy either. =]
author: Jason C. J.

description: For about 1.5 years, I ate dinner here 1-2 times a week. The food is pretty good but not excellent. The service was pretty good and it seems to be family run. The prices aren't bad either. I honestly stopped going because I was trying to eat healthier. It had nothing to do with them.
author: Diane M.

description:
Been here 4-5 times and everytime I had the same thing. Why?? Let me explain. 

Well, the last time I came here (before coming here so frequently) was probably 10 yrs ago and I remembered it sucked. My family went there one time just to try it out again and they called me and told me they had "hand pulled noodles" !!! No Way!!! I love "hand pulled noodles". That's it!! I'm going!!! One day during lunch I went there and  I ordered their seafood hand pull noodles(Dai Lowe Mein). Five minutes has past and i noticed that this place is pretty grimey lookin. Another 5 mins past. Now i noticed there are flies flyin around! Damn!! Now I remember why I didnt like this place. It's different owners but i was thinkin it's the same crappy food. My noodles finally came and I was starvin. I started enhaling this noodle. Wait, I noticed something!! This is pretty DAMN good. There were a lot of veggies and chunks of fish, squid and shrimp!! Their noodles were really fresh I gotta admit. The best part is, it was only around 5 bucks or so. To me, it was way better than any of the noodle houses around there. 

Now back to the question. why don't try something else from there? Because I Hella Like Those Damn Noodles!!! :) I'm out!!!
author: RICKY C.

description: Dan Dan Mein (peanutbutta noodul), Onion pancake, pork dumplings, tofu beef.  $25 dinner for 3.  We were stuffed like pigs, then roasted and put into pork bun! (yancan accent))jk  i think i could eat fifty dumplings i swear, PB noodles were too thick.. I ve eaten here before and they always have tasty dishes that you dont find at every chinese restaurant.  Good place to get a little adventurous with chinese food w/o forkin out alotta dough.
author: JASON L.

description:
Surprisingly low profile but above average Chinese restaurant. Although the menu does not have anything exotic or rare, to be honest it actually looks like the same menu as in most other chinese restaurants in SF, still the quality of the cuisine was surprising and actually very good.
The Szechuan beef and general Cho style prawns (yes you are not misreading :)) dishes were actually excellent.
author: Cedrick C.

description: I love their peanut butter and cucumber cold noodles. And their spicy wontons. Their food has been pretty good although service can be lacky at times.
author: Vivian L.

description: MMmmm....service can be spotty at times, but my hubby and I love their Schezuan Beef!  Everytime we order it, the waitress raises an eye brow and asks, "You sure?  Verrrrrry spicy!!!"  Oh man, I want some now...
author: Jessica H.

description:
wow! good thing i wasn't a lucky one to experience rude service here. seems like it happens quite often. i do recall the place was a lil filthy. anyhow, i love the dandan mein. it was really good, packed with favors. i also enjoy the seafood noodle soup. that is good. i think they must of make their own noodles of something. its kinda chewy and taste like fresh noodles, not them egg noodle package you find at your local grocery store. the textures really good. the seafood noodle soup is probably made with real brooth, not just water and msg because it carries a body and a thick to it. the dandan mein is just awesome, can almost be compare to San Tung's cold noodles. like everyone says, the green onion pancake is good, but i personally wouldn't go there just for that. i would definitely go back there for the dandan mein and seafood noodle soup especially on cold winter days. 

i guess i was one of the lucky ones that didn't get crappy service... so i give them a four stars. generally, i don't expect much from neighborhood chinese place. i don't speak mandarin either, guess i must of went there on a good day. all in all, i think this place is worth a try since there are less and less good places for real Chinese food without having to go into Chinatown.
author: Jules D.

description: I thought the food was excellent here. I'm not quite familiar with Beijing style food, but this place definitely gave me a good impression. Try their house specials. Lots of flavor. If you are sensitive to spices or salty food, you might want to turn around and try something else. As for me, I love flavorful food (and no, not just the salty shit).
author: Andrew W.

description: Little Beijing is one of my favorite chinese restaurants.  Some of my favorites are green onion pancake, pork dumplings, shrimp, pork and chives dumplings, and beijing bean sauce noodles.  The soy milk and chinese donuts are good too.
author: Stacey L.

description: This place is a rare find in SF, where most of the Chinese fare could be described as greasy spoon Cantonese. This is also a simple family style hole in the wall, but it is Beijing style. The flavors, I am told by Chinese friends, are spot on authentic. Everyone suggests the green onion pancakes, but I would suggest going with the shrimp ones instead. They are flakier and tastier. The noodle dishes, on a good day, are excellent, just like many favorite Mandarin eateries on the Penninsula (which are actually as a whole, better than those in SF--perhaps because this is where larger immigrant communities live?), and compares to casual eateries in Beijing. Skip this place if you are there at peak hours. The quality noticeably goes down.
author: 和子

description: Like the taste of this place.  Nothing special, but the flavor is heavy (which I love).  Ask for recommendations, try new stuff.  :)
author: Jason L.

description:
I'm from Beijing so I want say Northern Chinese food there is relatively much more authentic than other Chinese restaurants. 
      Onion pancake is not authentic but tastes really good. 
      Chinese chives pancake is the best in SF, but don't try if your not used to eat a lot chives:).
      Sichuan spicy cool noodle is also my favorate!!! 
      Beijing chaomian is authentic. 
      I went there 4 times and tried different dishes that I don't remember their English names....sorry about that. But generally speaking it is a pretty good restaurant if you like spicy and Northern Chinese food.

BUT! I have to say the owner(manager) is kinda rude. She got cranky to her staff some times and showed less patience with costumers. Since she is also Chinese so I just ate it up and didn't say anything. But not matter with which standard, American or Chinese, she is rude sometimes.

So if you only want to enjoy food there, it's definitely a great place to go, you won't be disappointed. But you might also "enjoy" the manager's bad manners if your unlucky...  

Hope this review is helpful.
author: Sophie Y.

description: The General's Chicken and the Green onion potato pancakes are awesome. My sister and I  swear by this place. I actually prefer the take out option, as the dine in service can be somewhat lacking. The price is right and the delivery time is pretty decent.
author: Steve M.

description:
Forget this place....
...decided to give the ill-mannered bobble headed waitress another chance, you know how cyclical poor attitude can be with females.
The crappy service still prevailed, the food was mediocre.
Better to go to San Tung, Mandarin Islamic, Tong Palace, Taste of Formosa, Mayflower, or any other decent establishments.  
The waitress still had grudge attitude for my party walking out on her, she did not warm up nor even crack a smile.  Most waitress/waiters will fill your tea when empty, give you a new plate when your's is full, bring more napkins, rice, or any other standard necessities!
After giving the place a second chance, I have to say the food is pasable, the service and attitude will turn your stomach.
author: Patrick G.

description: The place is a jewel.  They do everything well, not just their fabulous green onion pancakes!  I favor their Generals Chicken, homemade soups, and handmade noodles over many other places.  The polite old-fashioned gentleness of the wait staff, and the ease in which they interact, would be enough to bring you back.  Prices are comfortable, so just order to your heart's content like I do. Place is clean, but the focus is on the cooking, not the decor.  Patronized by locals, young, old, families. Like I said, it's a jewel.
author: Judy A.

description: very authentic. great soy milk and oil sticks.
author: kim w.

description: Difficult to find good Chinese in the city even w/ the millions of restaurants. This one is probably one of the best. Excellent food. The green onion pancakes are great. So is the eggplant. It's a small place, so maybe nicer to just get it to go.
author: N L.

description: First of all, do NOT ask for a fork. If you do, you will get what I like to call, the 'Treatment'. I learned to use chopsticks quickly although like a good American I naturally gravitate towards a utensil that enables me to shove as much food as possible into my mouth at one given time. Chopsticks are a good thing. I should say that there is a touch of nostalgia encapsulating this review because I spent my high school days living on 21st and Moraga and have eaten at Little Beijing for more than a decade. Their consistency has amazed me. I'm surprised by the not so positive reviews. I do always order the same dishes though so maybe I'm missing out on something. Here's what they do better than anyplace I have found yet: Green Onion Pancakes (when you eat in the restaurant look around, you will most likely see it on everybody's table), Beef  with Broccoli (best flavor! nice cuts of beef! not all chewy or stringy or otherwise frightening!), I love to pour the sauce over my rice....mmmmm, General Tsou's Chicken is the best I have ever had--theirs is what sold me on the dish in the first place (although I haven't tried it at every single place in the city--let me know if someone thinks there is a better one) and my Mom who is a little more adventurous than I am always likes whatever weird thing she orders. I'm sorry I can't think of any of her favorite dishes right now. I guess I'm kind of about 'me' when I go out to dinner with my Mom. Oh Little Beijing, why won't you deliver all the way across the city to me? You're mean. But you know I'll get my ass on a 71 Noriega bus one of these days and come crawling back to you. I think I'll have to transfer though. Ugh.
author: Magi C.

description: giving one star because they service soy bean milk or breakfast is good. not going to recomment for having any dinner at all. it does not teaste Beijin dishes at all. sorry if you are from Asian Northern China. don't even think about that. you are better cook than them.  when you walked in the restaurant smelt old old carpet ... three dishes was about $ 25.00....
author: kthy k.

description: This place is pretty good. A friend took me here and I'd come here again just to have their dishes. I especially like their spicy potstickers with rice..its just soo good. The lady speaks mandarin and english. Shes seems very nice so I give the service a good rate on that. Overall the price is cheap but the food is good.
author: Miss D.
